Tomah Winning Fight (L a ( ro>>e Tribune, March 27. 19:W) A battle royal between the federal government and our neighboring cil> of Tomah, to all appearances, has ended in victory for Tomah. proposal brought forth by the Indian bureau in Washington to raze the Indian hoarding school buildings in Tomah and uith salvaged material establish a rehabilitation project for the Winnebagoes in that region died cjuietlv in the House of Representatives last week when Congressman Griswold, with the support of Merlin Hull, succeeded in tacking an amendment on the interior department's appropriation bill prohibiting the bureau from using its funds to tear down the buildings. The action should save the Indian school property for al least a >ear, >ay Tomah citizens, who went to bat iull force in opposing the proposal. During that time they will continue to put on the pressure to have either the state or federal government make some use of the property. They suggest utilizing them for office room or perhaps a CCC or soil conservation camp, maintaining that the buildings can be repaired and made usable at little expense. contrary to what the government officials say. Apparently this is just another classic example of how inefficient government business is sometimes. The Indian school at Tomah represents an investment of some $500,000 in federal funds, sunk into the property during the past 50 years in an experiment in Indian education that did not work. Now the officials in Washington have decided to try a new plan, rehabilitating the Indians by^ expending some more money to undo what it has already done and do some more experimenting. Arguments of the Tomahites that this is not government economy are convincing, and they should be complimented in publicizing the issue to the nation as they bave done.
